Graphical abstract The impregnation parameters setting is an essential strategy to find efficient active phase precursors in heterogeneous catalysts due to the close connection between the chemistry of impregnated aqueous solution and the nature of metal-support interactions. In this work, the effect of impregnation solution pH on active NiWS phase formation was studied. Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation of a W/Al2O3-based catalyst using aqueous nickel-citric acid (CA) solutions (CA/Ni=2) at different pH values (0.3, 3.4, 5.1 and 8.7). The citric acid presence and the impregnation pH influenced the NiWS phase formation. Citric acid provided isolation to supported metal species avoiding strong metal-support interactions, delaying nickel reduction at higher temperatures and decreasing WS2 sintering when compared with a free-citric acid catalyst. An increase of 2.2 times in NiWS fraction was related to these citric acid features. Furthermore, the solution pH influenced the aqueous and supported nickel speciation. Dispersed nickel species were associated with AlO-Ni-Cit surface complexes generated by the adsorption of [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3− or [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− over alumina surface. In turn, these surface complexes were associated with a higher W sulfidation. 3-fold increases in Ni/W/Al2O3 catalytic activity for hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene were reached by the presence of citric acid and a pH of nickel-citric acid solution around 5. Therefore, the active NiWS species formation in Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts was improved with citric acid addition and furthermore, it was notably optimized by the control of the nickel species via tuned impregnation pH. Keywords NiWS Nickel-citrate complex Solution pH Hydrodesulfurization 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene 1 Introduction The growing demand for ultra-low sulfur diesel (ULSD) requires an increasing performance for hydrotreating (HDT) units, particularly in the deep hydrodesulfurization (HDS) step. The main challenge in deep HDS consists in improving the catalytic activity towards the most refractory molecules such as the 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophenes (46DMDBT) [1,2]. In this molecule, the direct desulfurization (DDS) route is disadvantaged due to steric hindrance of the sulfur atom by the position of the methyl groups [3,4]. Therefore, the desulfurization through the hydrogenation of aromatic rings (HYD) could overcome the DDS limitations [5]. Thus, the new catalysts need to have enhanced HYD function. The industrial HDS process uses γ-Al2O3-supported catalysts based on MoS2 or WS2 particles promoted by Co o Ni. Notably, the sulfide nickel-tungsten-alumina (NiW/Al2O3) catalysts possess an outstanding performance in hydrogenation reactions that provide a high potential for alkyl-dibenzothiophenes conversion [6,7]. In this regard, the specific activity of promoted phase (the so-called “NiWS” phase) is significantly higher than the non-promoted WS2 phase [8–10]. Therefore, the catalyst optimization must be directed towards increasing the surface concentration of this mixed phase. However, NiW/Al2O3 catalysts have presented inadequate formation of the active NiWS mixed phase, as compared with Mo-based catalysts. The related literature agrees that typical NiW/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited limited formation of active NiWS phase due to strong metal-support interactions [9–13]. Strong W-alumina interactions, Al-O-W, made tungsten sulfidation difficult. Moreover, nickel migration into the support from the affinity of Ni2+ ion to Al3+ vacant sites of the alumina support occurred and it decreased the availability of nickel promoter. The modifications of traditional alumina or new supports have helped to modulate the strength of metal-support interactions [14–23], although not necessary getting significant improvement in the WS2 promotion. Low contents of NiWS also have been associated with sulfidation temperature differences of metal-supported species, causing premature Ni sulfidation and subsequent segregation of Ni- and W-sulfides phases [10–12]. Nevertheless, the incorporation of citric acid (CA) in the impregnation solutions during the NiW catalysts synthesis has shown a remarkable increase in the formation of the NiWS phase and as a result in the HDS catalytic activity [24–26], as well as it has been published for CoMoS and NiMoS catalysts [27–35] or using others complexing agents [23,34–39]. In general, it has been agreed that the catalytic improvements are related to combined effects involving the weakening of metal-support interaction and nickel sulfidation delay. In addition to the above, a fair amount of data for CA physicochemical properties has been published [40][40, and references therein]. From these works, CA is highly soluble and it is environmentally harmless. Moreover, it has economics advantages over other complexing agents used to improve NiW catalysts It is well known that the characteristics of the catalysts are closely related to the interactions generated in metal deposition steps [41,42]. Although the implementation of the complex agents in the catalyst synthesis is apparently simple, the chemistry involved in the genesis of the active phase is quite complicated. However, practical way to regulate surface interactions and consequently to optimize the formation of active NiWS phase could be carried out through the control of macroscopic variables that influence directly the involved chemical equilibria. In this regard, solution pH value plays an important role in the formation of aqueous ions complexes and the surface speciation on the support controlling the metal-support interactions [41–45]. Accordingly, different aqueous metal complexes may be formed which could generate suitable precursors for the active NiWS phase. In summary, the nature of the promoting effect of citric acid on NiW catalysts has been rarely discussed in the open literature to our knowledge and it has not taken into consideration the effect of impregnation pH. Therefore, the effect of the pH for the impregnation solution on various steps of the synthesis for Ni/W/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and its impact on the catalytic performance in HDS of 46DMDBT was studied in this paper. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Various Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared with citric acid (CA) and impregnated by successive wetness technique at different pH values. Low-temperature (~273K) sol-gel technique [46] and calcination at 773K for 3h in static air atmosphere was used to prepare the γ-Al2O3 support. Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts contained 20wt.% of tungsten and 3.8wt.% of nickel (molar Ni/(Ni+W)=0.37) supported on sieved alumina (150–180μm). Tungsten was first impregnated with an aqueous solution of ammonium metatungstate hydrate, (NH4)6W12O40·xH2O. The resulted tungsten-alumina base catalyst was named W/Al2O3. Later, a mixed nickel–citric acid solution (molar CA/Ni=2) with specific pH value (Ni–Cit solution) was impregnated on the W/Al2O3 base catalyst. This CA/Ni value was chosen based on the maximum stoichiometry for complexation [40,47]. A nickel-tungsten (NiW) catalyst without CA was also prepared by the same procedure and it was taken as a reference. Details about an equivalent NiW catalyst supported on a commercial γ-Al2O3 can be found in a previous work [48]. After each impregnation steps, the catalysts were aged for 12h at room temperature and then dried at 373K for 12h. NiW catalysts prepared with citric acid were designated as (x)CNiW, where x represent the pH value of Ni–Cit solution used for catalyst impregnation. For Ni solutions preparation, nickel nitrate hexahydrate, (Ni(NO3)2·(6H2O)) was used as Ni precursor and citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·H2O) as complexing agent. A 25vol.% ammonia or nitric acids aqueous solutions were used to solutions pH adjusts. Several Ni–Cit solutions were prepared at different pH values keeping constant the Ni2+ concentration at 0.7M. To ensure equilibrium; the solutions remained at room temperature for 24h. Caution: The combination of ammonium hydroxide, nickel nitrate and citric acid causes highly exothermic reaction, and violent explosion may occur. To avoid a violent reaction, it is widely recommended that nickel nitrate and citric acid solutions should be carefully added on cooled ammonium hydroxide and the components should be mixed slowly. 2.2 Nitrogen physisorption The BET surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution for the synthesized support were measured with a Quantachrome iQ instrument using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm. Before the measurement, the sample was degassed (<10−2 Pa) at 623K for 6h. The surface area was obtained from the adsorption isotherm data (0.1<P/P0 <0.3) using the multi-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The total pore volume was determined by N2 adsorption at P/P0 =0.99. The pore size distribution was obtained from the desorption isotherm by the BJH method and the pore diameter corresponds to the average value. 2.3 Chemical equilibrium diagrams Nickel and nickel-citrate aqueous speciation diagrams were performed using Medusa software [49]. Several diagrams were constructed considering the counterions variation derived from metal precursor salts and pH adjusters. The ionic strength effect was considered due to the high ionic concentration in experimental solutions. Accordingly, the determinations of the activity coefficients were calculated by an approximation of the Helgeson–Kirkham-Flower model [49–51]. All calculations were carried out at a standard temperature (298K) and fixed molar concentrations of Ni2+ and Cit3−, 0.7 and 1.4M, respectively. 2.4 Ultraviolet and visible spectroscopy (UV–vis) UV–vis spectra for aqueous solutions and solids were recorded in a Lambda 35 spectrometer in the 200–1000 range and using an optical length of 0.2cm. For liquid samples, the spectra were recorded in absorption mode while spectra for solids were given as the Kubelka–Munk function (Eq. (1)) using a diffuse reflectance integration sphere. (1) F ( R ∞ ) = ( 1 − R ∞ ) 2 2 R ∞ R ∞ is the reflectance of a sample with an infinite thickness (~5mm). As a standard, a magnesium oxide tablet was used. 2.5 Infrared spectroscopy Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra in transmittance mode were collected in a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrometer in the 1100–1900cm−1 range. An average of 30 scans per sample with a resolution of 8cm−1 formed each spectrum. The solid samples were finely grounded and pressed in KBr pellets (~7wt.% of catalyst). Aqueous solutions were analyzed using an Attenuated Total Reflectance (ATR) accessory. 2.6 Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) The TPR experiments for dried solids were carried out in an AMI-80 apparatus. About 0.1g of sample placed in a quartz sample cell (U-shaped) for each analysis. Before TPR experiment, the samples were pretreated in situ at 373K for 1h under Ar flow. The reduction step performed under a stream of 10vol.% of H2/Ar (50 cm3·min−1), with a heating rate of 10K/min up to 1173K. A thermal conductivity detector was used to sense variations in the composition of the reduction products. Additionally, a Thermostar Pfeiffer Mass Spectrometer (MS) was used to identify the components of the output stream. A moisture trap was used to prevent measurements interferences. 2.7 High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) The HRTEM analyses for sulfided catalysts performed with a JEOL-2100F TEM (200kV) instrument equipped with a Link ISIS micro-analysis system. Its resolution was 0.19nm. The high-resolution images were captured digitally with a Gatan CCD digital camera. Previously to HRTEM analysis, the samples were sulfided under activation conditions (see Section 2.9) and isolated under Ar atmosphere to avoid air contact. Prior to analyses, the freshly sulfide samples were finely ground, ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and collected on a carbon-coated copper grid. In the sulfide state, alumina-supported W catalysts exhibited WS2 slabs characteristic of its layered structure. The average number of layers per stack ( N ¯ ) and the average stack length ( L ¯ ) were calculated from examination of about 600 particles spread across at least 10 high-resolution images per sample. The statistical calculations were made according to Eqs. (2) and (3) [52,53], respectively: (2) N − = Σ i = 1 n n i N i Σ i = 1 n n i (3) L − = Σ i = 1 n n i l i Σ i = 1 n n i where li is the slab length of a slab-particle, ni the number of particles with a li length or Ni layers, and Ni the number of layers in the particle i. 2.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The XPS studies for sulfide catalysts were carried out in an AXIS UltraDLD Kratos Analytical spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical analyzer operating at fixed pass energy of 40eV and working under vacuum (<10−6 Pa). Before analyses, the samples were freshly sulfided (see the next Section, 2.9) and transferred into the spectrophotometer under Ar atmosphere. All the data were acquired using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV, 150W), and the binding energies (BE) were corrected taking C 1s (248.6eV) as a reference. The surface analyzed on the sample was 300×700μm and it allows a representative characterization of the whole sample. The W 4f and Ni 2p spectra were analyzed using the software “XPS processing” and applying a Shirley background subtraction and Gaussian–Lorentzian decomposition parameters with 30/70 Gaussian/Lorentzian proportion. 2.9 Activation of catalysts Prior to HRTEM, XPS and catalytic activity experiments, the dried solids were sulfided ex situ in a PYREX linear reactor at 673K for 2h using a heating rate of 3 K·min−1 and 15mol% of H2S/H2 stream (60cm3·min−1). The sulfide catalysts were cooled down to room temperature under H2S flow; then the system flushed with N2 for about half an hour. 2.10 Catalytic activity evaluation Catalytic activity for sulfide catalysts was evaluated by the 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (46DMDBT) hydrodesulfurization (HDS). The reactions took place in a high-pressure batch reactor (Parr Instrument Co.) equipped with magnetic agitation and wall-baffles to prevent the vortex formation. The reaction mixture consisted in 7.3×10−4 mol of 46DMDBT dissolved in 100cm3 of dodecane (300ppm of sulfur) and 250mg of fresh sulfide catalyst. The reaction system was flushed with N2 to displace air and avoids oxygen interference. Then, reactor was pressurized at 1.4MPa with N2 and heated to the reaction temperature (593K). Subsequently, N2 was vented slowly until 1.4MPa, and then H2 was introduced up to reaction pressure (5.4MPa). Reaction was carried out with vigorous agitation (1200rpm). At these conditions, there were not internal/external diffusion limitations [54]. The reaction time was considered to start from the incorporation of H2. Small samples volumes were periodically collected and analyzed by gas chromatograph (Varian CP3800) equipped with an HP-5 column (5% phenyl-methyl-silicone, 30m×0.25mm) and a flame ionized detector. Catalytic activity was considered as the initial hydrodesulfurization reaction rate. It was defined as 46DMDBT moles transformed to desulfurized products per second and per gram of sulfided catalyst, mol·s−1·g−1 . An industrial NiW/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 25.7 wt.% WO3 and 3.8wt.% NiO was used as references and named NiW-Ind. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Impregnation solutions of nickel In order to determine the effect of impregnation pH, the equilibrium species in nickel and nickel-citric acid aqueous solutions were calculated. Fig. 1 shows a representative molar fraction distribution diagram of nickel species as a function of pH for a nickel nitrate solution (without citric acid). A simple nickel nitrate solution (pH 3.7 and pale-green) composed only by the hexahydrate nickel compound [Ni(H2O)6]2+, was used as a reference (located as a double line). Nickel speciation did not change by the decrease of pH value, confirmed by UV–vis. However, increasing the solution pH led to the formation of both aqueous soluble nickel-ammonia and aqueous insoluble nickel hydroxide complexes, [Ni(H2O)6−n(NH3)n]2+ and [Ni(OH)2(H2O)4]2+, respectively. UV–vis spectra of decanted solution showed typical profiles for [Ni(H2O)6−n(NH3)n]2+ complexes [55]. Fig. 2 shows that the incorporation of citric acid drastically changed the chemical equilibria in the nickel impregnation solution. The citric acid incorporation prevented formation of insoluble nickel species and soluble Ni–Cit-species formed instead. In this sense, solution pH increase produced three consecutive deprotonations of the carboxylic groups in citric acid and generated citrate ligands capable of coordinating with nickel ions [40]. In consequence, four successive Ni–Cit complexation species were predicted at this conditions: [Ni(H2Cit)(H2O)5]+, [Ni(HCit)(H2O)4], [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3– and [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4–, respectively. The predominant presence of [Ni(H2O)6]2+ ions at acidic pH values was consistent with a thermodynamically non-favored citric acid dissociation. A predominant formation of Ni–Cit complexes predicted around pH 3-8 showed maximum molar fractions at pH 3.3 and 5.8, corresponding to [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3– and [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4–, respectively. At higher pH values the appearance of [Ni(NH3)n(H2O)6−n]2+ and [NH4(Cit)]2– complexes occurred, due to the excess amount of ammonium ion in an aqueous solution. Thus, the replacement of citrate by ammonium ligand in [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4– complex, originated an increase in the molar fraction of non-coordinated citrate ion (Cit3–). According to the predicted nickel complexation, the UV–vis spectra of Ni–Cit solutions showed a significant blueshift of the d–d transition for octahedral coordinated nickel ion (d8), as the pH solution increased (Fig. 3 ). Additionally, a detectable color change was observed with the changes in the nickel ion coordination (Table 1 ). These behaviors were related to a progressive substitution of original aqua ligands of [Ni(H2O)6]2+ ion by stronger ligands, such as citrate [56]. In turn, this was consistent with the successive deprotonation of carboxylic acids groups in the citric acid molecule, increasing the amount of citrate ligands capable of coordinating with nickel ion and form Ni–Cit complexes. IR spectroscopy identified the type of citric acid coordination, complementing the UV–vis results. Fig. 4 displayed the IR spectra for Ni–Cit solutions at different pH values while Table 2 shows the absorption bands assignments. A nickel nitrate (Fig. 4a) and a citric acid solution (Fig. 4b) were used as references. From the nickel nitrate spectrum, the presence of NO bonds of NO3 − counterions corresponded to the bands located at 1386 and 1327cm−1 while the band at 1633cm−1 with the OH- group of aqueous solvent [57]. In Fig. 4b, the citric acid spectra presented two main bands located at 1711 and 1216cm−1 and attributed to strong absorption due to ν(CO) and ν(CO) bonds of carboxylic groups, respectively. Additionally, the broadband found between 1500 and 1300cm−1 could be attributed to CH vibrations [57,58]. The IR spectrum for the Ni–Cit solution at pH 0.3 (Fig. 4c) exhibited the same bands as the reference compounds (citric acid and nickel nitrate), indicating that carboxylic acids in citric acid remains undissociated and non-bonded. However, the solution pH increase led to a successive deprotonation of carboxylic groups represented by a decrease in the intensity of carboxylic acid absorption bands. In parallel, enhanced intensity for strong antisymmetric (νas) and relatively strong symmetric (νs) carboxylate stretch indicated the metal-coordination of deprotonated carboxylic groups. In particular, the spectra of Ni–Cit solutions with pH 3.4, 5.1 and 8.7 (Fig. 4d–f) showed absorption bands at 1602 and 1567cm−1, associated with νas carboxylate stretch while the band at 1413cm−1 could be assigned to νs carboxylate stretch. In this sense, the presence of these groups evidenced the carboxylic acid coordination. As seen in Table 2, these spectra exhibited Δν values between 152 and 189 cm−1 related to a bridge bidentate coordination mode [58,59], consistent with [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3− or [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− complexes [60]. Moreover, the presence of a weak shoulder around 1703–1713cm−1 showed that a fraction of undissociated carboxylic group remained at pH 3.4 and 5.1 and could be related to the presence of [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3−, besides the presence of [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4−. For the Ni-Cit solution at pH 8.7, only [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− species was evidenced. 3.2 Support The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm for the γ-Al2O3 support is shown in Fig. 5 . It corresponds to a type IV isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loop, characteristic for mesoporous materials [61]. The presence of a sharp adsorption step between P/P0:0.7–0.9 suggests that mesopores had a relative well-defined array. Consistent with the above, a regular and narrow unimodal distribution of mesopores with mean diameter size around 8nm was formed (Fig. 5). In addition, 322 m2·g−1 of BET area and 1.2 cm3·g−1 of total volume pore were obtained. According to open literature [62], the textural properties of this homemade γ-Al2O3 support were suitable for potential implementation in diesel cuts hydrotreating. 3.3 Impregnated solids Diffuse Reflectance UV–vis spectra for dried impregnated solids are in Fig. 6 . The band located between 200 and 400nm could be assigned to O2− →W6+ charge transfer transitions, corresponding to the excitation of electrons from the valence band to the conduction band. In particular, the region between 200 and 275nm has been associated with tetrahedral tungsten species (WTh), while 275–370nm with octahedral tungsten species (Woh) [63]. The intensities ratio of Woh and WTh region, Woh/WTh ratio, can provide qualitative information about the size of the WOX polytungstates species [15]. As seen in Fig. 7 , the Woh/WTh ratio for W/Al2O3 base catalyst changed after the second impregnation step. Comparison of the Woh/WTh ratio of W/Al2O3 with those for dried samples impregnated at similar solutions pH, NiW and (3.4)CNiW, suggested that the re-dispersion of tungsten species occurred mainly influenced by the nickel solution. In (x)CNiW samples, no significant effect of solution pH on the re-dispersion of tungsten species was observed. In turn, the W–Cit complexes formation as being responsible for the invariability of Woh/WTh ratio was discarded, because an excess of citric acid on tungsten would be necessary [64]. However, the presence of citric acid influenced the W-support interaction and not the solution pH. This issue is further discussed below. Meanwhile, the bands located within 370–1100nm were related to the nickel ion structure, and they are summarized in Table 3 . Compared with their respective impregnation solutions, nickel d–d transition for dried NiW sample remained unchanged indicating that aqueous [Ni(H2O)6]2+ ion was preserved after the drying step and suggested that nickel-support interaction was ruled by an electrostatic adsorption. In contrast, the nickel d–d transitions for dried (x)CNiW samples exhibited a redshift related to a decrease in the overall strength of their binding ligands. Accompanying this, the change of color for (x)CNiW solids was noticed, from respective nickel impregnation solution color (Table 1) to light-green. In accordance with spectrochemical series, this bathochromic shift was related to the replacement of H2O- ligands in nickel ion by a weaker surface ligand (AlO) forming a nickel inner-sphere complex [65,66], AlO-Ni-Cit. Based on the (0.3)CNiW spectra, nickel d–d transitions for the rest of (x)CNiW spectra showed a blueshift (λ2: 701→676nm) indicating higher overall strength of coordinating ligand. This observation suggested that the grafted nickel complexes on (x)CNiW (pH≥3.4) retained, totally or partially, the citrate linkages from [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3− or [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− complexes. Whereas for (0.3)CNiW, the non-surface ligands could be H2O- ligands, weaker than citrate. In order to investigate the citric acid coordination after drying, IR spectra for (x)CNiW solids are given in Fig. 8 . The spectra showed an intense broadband at 1500–1700cm−1 related to adsorbed H2O on the alumina support that could hide the as νas carboxylate signals. Meanwhile, the band at 1335cm−1 corresponded to δ(CH) linkages and 1401cm−1 to νs carboxylate mode. The last absorption band evidenced carboxylic group coordination. Consistent with DR-UV–vis results, adsorbed nickel on (0.3)CNiW solids not linked with citrate, so the spectra did not show the νs carboxylate absorption (Fig. 8a), unlike the other (x)CNiW solids. There was no clear evidence of Cit-alumina surface coordination. However, adsorption of citrate ligands on alumina surface groups was previously evidenced [24,67], and this possibility was not discarded. Fig. 9 displays the TPR profiles for dried solids. The reduction profile for the NiW solid (Fig. 9a) showed a first peak centered at ~610K with a shoulder at 683K, both could be ascribed to the reduction of nickel superficial phase [13]. The second peak centered at 880K was related to the reduction of nickel–polytungstates phases [68]. In this case, there were no bands related to the formation of aluminates because the NiW solid was submitted to mild thermal conditions. The third peak at 973–1123K can be ascribed to easily reducible W species [69]. Fig. 10 shows a representative TPR and MS profile for dried (x)CNiW catalysts. Since (x)CNiW catalysts were only dried, their TCD signals corresponded to the H2 consumption and the formation of CO, CO2 and CH4 from citric acid decomposition. The first TPR peak at 669K was assigned to a simultaneous decomposition of citric acid (660K) and a first step of nickel reduction (680K). The symmetry of this peak would indicate a homogenous distribution of Ni species on the surface. No signals related to thermal decomposition of pure citric acid were observed (425–525K [70]). Based on spectroscopy characterization, the decomposition of citric acid at higher temperature could be associated with nickel complexation and/or adsorption on the surface. In this sense, it has been reported that the presence of citric acid slows down the process of sulfidation of metal precursors (Ni or Co) [24,30,31,71] and it induced an isolating effect on the Ni (or Co) controlled by the thermal decomposition of citric acid on the surface [24,71]. Accordingly, an equivalent isolating effect on the Ni was evidenced in the reduction process of the (x)CNiW catalysts. Therefore it was reasonable to assume that a similar effect occurs during sulfidation. Meanwhile, the TPR peaks at higher temperatures were not significantly shifted in presence of citric acid. However, the second bands centered at 902K were sharper defined when compared with NiW catalyst and suggesting more homogeneous particles. Finally, the third reduction peak (1103–1173K) showed a shoulder appearance around 1050K that can be considered evidence of more tungsten availability on the surface. Therefore, the re-dispersion of tungsten species could take place due to the presence of citric acid during the second impregnation step. In this sense, it has already been shown that the presence of citrate ligands causes a sharp drop in zeta-potential for oxide surfaces due to the substitution of oxide surface groups by negatively charged carboxylate groups over wide pH range [67–69,72]. In this sense, negative density caused by citric acid presence resulted in the electrostatic repulsion of aqueous W species charged negatively and resulted in weaker W-support interactions explaining the lower reduction temperature for W species and the invariability of the Woh/WTh ratio showed from DR-UV–vis spectra analysis. 3.4 Sulfided solids Fig. 11 shows representative HRTEM images for sulfide catalyst. The images revealed the typical black lines corresponding to WS2-like lamellar structure. The observed spacing between the black lines (0.61nm) matched with the interplanar spacing of the (002) basal plane in bulk WS2 [44,45]. At simple view, it appears that WS2 crystallites in (x)CNiW catalysts were more dispersed than NiW catalyst. In this sense, the crystallite length and stacking number histogram for WS2 particles are shown in Fig. 12 . Hence, a larger amount of WS2 crystallites having one or two slabs were formed on (x)CNiW catalysts (83%) than on the NiW counterpart (53%). The average slab length ( L ¯ ) and average stacked number ( N ¯ ) reveled that in (x)CNiW catalysts the WS2 particle size was smaller than in NiW catalyst. The presence of citric acid decreased the average slab length (from 3.0nm to around 2.5nm) and the average stacked number value (from 2.5 to 1.7 slabs) in the WS2 crystallites. These results suggested that citric acid contributed to prevent the sintering of WS2 phase during the sulfidation step, probably due to the isolation effect provided by the carbonaceous species. Meanwhile, the pH value of Ni–Cit solution showed no effect on the WS2 dispersion. As suggested above, the negative charge generated by carboxylate groups in citric acid limited to solution pH to regulate the surface charge and consequently on the WS2 dispersion. The W4f and Ni2p XPS spectra and decomposition of the sulfided catalysts are shown in Fig. 13 . Table 4 summarizes the relative composition and atomic ratios of Ni and W species obtained from the XPS spectra for the W4f and Ni2p core level for sulfide catalysts. For the NiW sample, 51% of available W entities were converted into WS2, 16% WSXOY and 33% WOX species while (x)CNiW catalysts showed an increased tungsten sulfidation degree (up to 68% WS2). However, selectivity in WOX species sulfidation showed significant differences in the (0.3)CNiW and (5.1)CNiW catalysts. For (5.1)CNiW, the WOX species were mainly converted to WS2 while the (0.3)CNiW catalyst was left as WSXOY. Meanwhile, (x)CNiW catalysts also showed high fraction of NiWS phase compared with NiW catalyst without citric acid (72 vs. 32%). Such increase could be related to the isolating effect on the nickel controlled by the thermal decomposition of citric acid, as evidenced by TPR experiments. In this sense, the delay in the nickel sulfidation allowed favorable conditions for the formation of the mixed NiWS phase i.e., simultaneous sulfidation of a greater amount of Ni and W. In turn, the value of W/Al and Ni/Al ratios also showed an increase with the presence of citric acid. This suggested that the addition of citric acid favored the surface dispersion of W and Ni. Thus, we could infer that the presence of citric acid caused a weaker W-support interaction and prevented metal sintering. Meanwhile, the higher value of Ni/Al ratio was found for the (5.1)CNiW catalyst, pointing out to the highest dispersion of nickel. Considering the UV–vis results, the presence of AlO–Ni–Cit surface complexes could be the precursors for better dispersed nickel in the sulfide state. However, the increase in the Ni-promotion for WS2 was provoked mainly by the nickel isolation provided by the presence of citric acid. 3.5 Catalytic evaluation for sulfided catalyst in the hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene The initial reaction rates for sulfide catalysts in the HDS of 46DMDBT reaction are depicted in Fig. 14 . The results show that the addition of citric acid in (x)CNiW catalysts resulted in an increase, at least two times, of the catalytic activity by comparison with NiW catalyst. This result could be related to a significant increase in NiWS phase formation associated to a combined effect provided by the citric acid, such as increased availability of metal species, grown degree of tungsten sulfidation, higher reduction temperature of nickel species and less sintering degree of WS2 particles. Another significant increase in the catalytic activity was noticed with the variation of pH of the Ni–Cit impregnation solution. From the (0.3)CNiW catalyst, the activity continuously increased to a maximum activity located at (5.1)CNiW, displaying around four times more activity than NiW catalyst and 22% higher than the reference NiW-Ind catalyst. Thereafter, the activity decreased again. From the comparison of (0.3)CNiW and (5.1)CNiW, the significant increase in activity cannot be only related to the high fraction of the active NiWS phase. In this regard, a greater sulfidation and almost the same average WS2 particle size indicated a higher WS2 dispersion. Furthermore, improved nickel dispersion may be preventing blocking of promoted sites due by larger NiSX particles. Consequently, an increase in the WS2 dispersion and greater availability of promoted sites could be related to such increases in HDS activity. According to the above, a correlation between the molar fraction of [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4−] complex and the catalytic activity in the HDS of 46DMDBT was found (Fig. 15 ). The transformation of 46DMDBT occurred through two parallel routes: (i) the direct desulfurization (DDS) led to the formation of 3,3′-bimethylbiphenyl (DMBP), and (ii) hydrogenation of aromatics rings (HYD) gave the intermediate 4,6-dimethyltetrahydrodibenzothiophene (THDBT), which after sulfur removal through C-S bond scission was converted to 3,3′-dimethylcyclohexylbenzene (DMCHB) and then to 3,3′-dimethylbicyclohexyl (DMBCH). Product yields and HYD/DDS selectivity ratios at 15% of 46DMDBT conversion are shown in Table 5 . For all catalysts, the 46DMDBT converted mainly via the HYD route with DMCHB as the main desulfurized product. However, the addition of citric acid for the (x)CNiW catalysts synthesis led to a slight improvement in the HYD pathway for this reaction through higher THDBT yield over DMBP yield (DDS route) when compared with NiW reference catalysts (without citric acid). 4 Conclusions The citric acid and pH solution of impregnated Ni-Cit solutions of Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts favored better dispersed and highly promoted active phase, resulting in significant increases in the hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene, as compared with conventional NiW catalyst. Theoretical calculations, UV–vis and ATR-FT-IR, spectroscopy evidenced the formation of different Ni complexes in the Ni-Cit solutions used for catalysts impregnation. Therefore, the nature of the Ni precursors could be controlled by the pH solution and allowed to find [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− species as efficient precursors for active NiWS phase. These Ni-Cit complexes favored dispersion of nickel species by grafting of the Ni-Cit complexes on the alumina surface, forming an AlO–Ni–Cit surface complex. The AlO–Ni–Cit surface complex was associated with increases in catalytic activity, related with higher W phase sulfidation, potentially enhancing the dispersion of accessible NiWS species. Regardless of solution pH, positive effects on the formation of the active NiWS phase were evidenced with citric acid. The presence of citric acid prevented strong metal-support interactions which lead to increased availability of metal species and higher degree of tungsten sulfiding. Possibly, the negativity of the carboxylate groups of citric acid dominated over the alumina surface charge causing charge repulsion with aqueous W species. In addition, citric acid provided an isolation effect to supported metal species. In the case of supported nickel species, citric acid delayed the nickel reduction process to higher temperatures increasing the WS2-promotion by Ni and the catalytic activity significantly increased. For W phase, HRTEM measurements showed that the presence of citric acid decreased sintering and induced smaller WS2 particles. In terms of the above, citric acid can substantially improve the active NiWS phase formation. However, the nature of the nickel precursor significantly influenced the NiWS dispersion. Therefore, the nature of the nickel precursors could be controlled by the pH solution and allowed to find efficient nickel precursors, [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4−], and thus, to optimize the formation of active NiWS species to appropriate synthesis conditions, in this case around pH 5. coredata.dc:description: The impregnation parameters setting is an essential strategy to find efficient active phase precursors in heterogeneous catalysts due to the close connection between the chemistry of impregnated aqueous solution and the nature of metal-support interactions. In this work, the effect of impregnation solution pH on active NiWS phase formation was studied. Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by impregnation of a W/Al2O3-based catalyst using aqueous nickel-citric acid (CA) solutions (CA/Ni=2) at different pH values (0.3, 3.4, 5.1 and 8.7). The citric acid presence and the impregnation pH influenced the NiWS phase formation. Citric acid provided isolation to supported metal species avoiding strong metal-support interactions, delaying nickel reduction at higher temperatures and decreasing WS2 sintering when compared with a free-citric acid catalyst. An increase of 2.2 times in NiWS fraction was related to these citric acid features. Furthermore, the solution pH influenced the aqueous and supported nickel speciation. Dispersed nickel species were associated with AlO-Ni-Cit surface complexes generated by the adsorption of [Ni(HCit)(Cit)(H2O)4]3− or [Ni(Cit)2(H2O)4]4− over alumina surface. In turn, these surface complexes were associated with a higher W sulfidation. 3-fold increases in Ni/W/Al2O3 catalytic activity for hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene were reached by the presence of citric acid and a pH of nickel-citric acid solution around 5. Therefore, the active NiWS species formation in Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts was improved with citric acid addition and furthermore, it was notably optimized by the control of the nickel species via tuned impregnation pH.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the solution pH in impregnation with citric acid and activity of Ni/W/Al2O3 catalysts
